document.docTitle: Reinhardorhynchus ruffinjonesi Diez & Monnens & Aguirre & Yurduseven & Jouk & Van Steenkiste & Leander & Schockaert & Reygel & Smeets & Artois 2021, comb. n.
document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomy and phylogeny of Koinocystididae (Platyhelminthes, Kalyptorhynchia) with the description of three new genera and twelve new species

subSubSection.paragraph:
Known distribution.
St. George , Tobacco Bay , Bermuda ( Type Locality) ( Karling 1978 )
.

New records and material.

), on the alga

deep, salinity 35 ‚Ä∞ (HU XIII .3.20‚Äì XIII .3.21). Two whole mounts from Siboney ( 19¬∞57‚Äô34‚ÄùN ; 75¬∞42‚Äô07‚ÄùW ), Santiago de Cuba , Cuba (
March 22, 2017
), intertidal, sand with organic matter, salinity 35 ‚Ä∞ (HU XIII .3.22‚Äì XIII .3.23). Eight whole mounts from Bueycab√≥n ( 19¬∞57‚Äô38‚ÄùN ; 76¬∞57‚Äô28‚ÄùW ), Santiago de Cuba , Cuba (February 6 & 21, 2018), fine-grained sand rich in organic matter,

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5.
Reinhardorhynchus ruffinjonesi ( Karling, 1978 )
comb. n.
. A, D, G & J, larger hook [specimens from Cuba, Punta Culebra (Panama), Brazil, and Bah√≠a Can Can (Panama), respectively]. B, E, H & K, smaller hook [specimens from Cuba, Punta Culebra (Panama), Brazil, and Bah√≠a Can Can (Panama), respectively]. C, F & I, distal spines of the cirrus [specimens from Cuba, Punta Culebra (Panama), and Brazil, respectively]. All with distal end toward top of figure.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. According to Karling (1978) ,
R . ruffinjonesi
comb. n.
is characterised by a cirrus with small sclerotised dots, a curved row of scale-like spines (15 Œºm maximum length), and two distal hooks (72 Œºm and 45 Œºm long, respectively). In addition, Karling (1978) describes a ‚Äúsmall, easily overlooked spiny diverticulum‚Äù in the cirrus. Our re-examination of the holotype of
R . ruffinjonesi
comb. n.
( Fig. 6A‚ÄìB ) reveals that the ‚Äúsmall sclerotised dots‚Äù of the cirrus described by Karling (1978) are in fact triangular spines of 1‚Äì2 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 2 Œºm; n = 20). These spines are larger in the ‚Äúspiny diverticulum‚Äù (4 Œºm; n = 9). The curved belt described by Karling (1978) , consists of a proximal part of large and scale-like spines, followed by a middle part of small spines, and a distal part of strong, more or less triangular spines. In the holotype , the spines in the proximal part of the row ( Fig. 6A : cps) are 6‚Äì9 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 8 Œºm; n = 15), smaller toward the distal end. The spines of the middle part are 1‚Äì2-Œºm-long ( xÃÑ = 2 Œºm; n = 10). In the distal part of the belt ( Fig. 6A : cds), the spines are 4‚Äì20 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 13 Œºm; n = 20), the most distal ones of which are curved ( Fig. 6B : ds) and 13‚Äì21 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 18 Œºm; n = 5).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 6.
Reinhardorhynchus ruffinjonesi ( Karling, 1978 )
comb. n.
. A‚ÄìF, hard structures of the copulatory bulb. A‚ÄìB, from the holotype. C‚ÄìD, specimen from Cuba. E, specimen from Punta Culebra (Panama). F, specimen from Brazil. E oriented with proximal end toward top of figure; the others with proximal end toward left of figure.

subSubSection.paragraph: In the specimens from Cuba ( Fig. 5A‚ÄìC & 6C‚ÄìD ), the copulatory bulb is 162‚Äì220 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 192 Œºm; n = 6). The cirrus ( Fig. 6C : ci) is armed with triangular spines of 1‚Äì2 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 2 Œºm; n = 27). The spiny belt is 149‚Äì247 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 176 Œºm; n = 10). In the proximal part of the belt ( Fig. 6C : cps), the spines are 5‚Äì9 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 7 Œºm; n = 31), with the size of the spines decreasing distally. In the middle part, the spines are 2‚Äì3-Œºm-long ( xÃÑ = 3 Œºm; n = 25). In the distal part ( Fig. 6C : cds), the spines are 6‚Äì18 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 12 Œºm; n = 26), the most distal ones of which ( Fig. 5C , 6C‚ÄìD : ds) are 6‚Äì15 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 12 Œºm; n = 9). The distal sclerotised hooks differ in size. The larger hook ( Fig. 5A , 6C‚ÄìD : h1) is 46‚Äì60 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 54 Œºm; n = 10) and 15‚Äì27 Œºm wide at its base ( xÃÑ = 21 Œºm; n = 10). The smaller hook ( Fig. 5B , 6C‚ÄìD : h2) is 21‚Äì32 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 27 Œºm; n = 10) and 11‚Äì21 Œºm wide at its base ( xÃÑ = 17 Œºm; n = 10).

In the specimens from Punta Culebra ( Panama ) ( Fig. 5D‚ÄìF , 6E ) the copulatory bulb is 339‚Äì348 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 344 Œºm; n = 2). The cirrus is armed with 2‚Äì3-Œºm-long triangular spines ( xÃÑ = 3 Œºm; n = 20). The belt of spines is 253‚Äì366 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 260 Œºm; n = 2), with spines of 3‚Äì13 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 8 Œºm; n = 26) in the proximal part and of 9‚Äì23-Œºm-long ( xÃÑ = 17 Œºm; n = 16) in the distal part. The most distal spines of the posterior part ( Fig. 5F ) are 20‚Äì21 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 21 Œºm; n = 3) and shark-tooth shaped, with a broad base, curved, and ending in a sharp tip. The larger distal hook ( Fig. 5D & 6E ) is 62 Œºm long (n = 2) and 33‚Äì34 Œºm wide at its base (n = 2). The smaller hook ( Fig. 5E ) is 26‚Äì33 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 30 Œºm; n = 2) and 15‚Äì16 Œºm wide at its base (n = 2).

In the specimen from Brazil ( Fig. 5G‚ÄìI , 6F ) the copulatory bulb is 165 Œºm long. No triangular spines were observed in the cirrus. The spiny belt is 165 Œºm long, with spines of 3‚Äì6 Œºm in length ( xÃÑ = 5 Œºm; n = 14) in the proximal part and a of 3‚Äì15 Œºm in length ( xÃÑ = 9 Œºm; n = 14) in the distal part. The most distal spines ( Fig. 5I , 6F : ds) of the distal part are shark-tooth shaped, with a broad base and a sharp curved tip, 15‚Äì20 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 18 Œºm; n = 3). The larger of the distal hooks ( Fig. 5G , 6F : h1) is 60 Œºm long and 22 Œºm wide at its base. The smaller hook ( Fig. 5H , 6F : h2) is 33 Œºm long and 16 Œºm wide at its base.

The specimen from Bah√≠a Can Can ( Panama ) ( Fig. 5J‚ÄìK ) has a copulatory bulb of 310 Œºm long. The cirrus is armed with 2‚Äì3-Œºm-long triangular spines ( xÃÑ = 2 Œºm; n = 20). The belt of spines is 251 Œºm long, with spines of 4‚Äì10 Œºm in length ( xÃÑ = 7 Œºm; n = 15) in the proximal part and of 2‚Äì18 Œºm in length ( xÃÑ = 10 Œºm; n = 27) in the distal part. The most distal spines of the distal part are triangular and curved, 16‚Äì24 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 18 Œºm; n = 4). The larger of the distal hooks ( Fig. 5J ) is 56 Œºm long and 30 Œºm wide at its base. The smaller hook ( Fig. 5K ) is 29 Œºm long and 20 Œºm wide at its base, slightly curved, ending in a rounded tip.
